His publications, research and consulting interests focus on social and technological change, the relationship between knowledge and practice, and applied values issues. His work in applied philosophy has entailed involvement with several academic and professional fields, including education, social work, business, public policy, creative arts, and various areas of science and engineering.

Hendrik Wagenaar is an associate professor of Public Policy at the Department of Public Administration at Leiden University. He publishes in the areas of urban governance, citizen participation, prostitution policy, administrative practice, complexity theory, and interpretive policy analysis. His new book Meaning in Action: Interpretation and Dialogue in Policy Analysis, has just been published by M.E. Sharpe.

abstract.p: The topic of the article is practice theory. Using a detailed example from public administration, we first discus the shortcomings of the model of practice as applied knowledge that we have dubbed the Received View. The first half of the article is a chronology of successive adaptations of the Received View. These adaptations have gradually brought the Received View more in accordance with the practice-oriented critique in social theory and research of recent years. These adaptations fall short, however, of offering a theoretical account that explains the relationships among practice, knowledge, and context. These adaptations do not enable us to show, as we wish to do, how knowledge and context can be explained in terms of—and are evoked within—practice, and not the other way round—and that this transpires within real worlds each of which has its own unique constraints and affordances, histories and futures. In the second half of the article, we pick up on a relational conception of practice, knowledge, and context in which practice is distinct and primary. To develop this aspect of practice theory, we make use of some key concepts from modern Japanese philosophy. The nondualist posture of Japanese philosophy gives rise to a useful conceptualization of the dynamic and fluid relationships among practice, the characteristics of the situation at hand, and the epistemic elements of practice itself. In this final section, we introduce three concepts that help capture this dynamic, relational understanding of practice: “actionable understanding,” “ongoing business,” and “the eternally unfolding present.”

sec.title: Introduction: Practice and Knowledge of the World—the Received View
sec.p: What is it that people—both professionals and lay people—do when they find themselves in situations that need to be resolved, or in routine situations that need to be carried forward effectively? How do they go about doing this? And how can we account for the fact that under ordinary circumstances people usually manage to arrive at a course of action that is acceptable to themselves and others? More broadly, what do people do when they engage in practice? Roughly speaking, by practice we mean any kind of activity the meaning of which (including the purpose) is derived from a given context. Scratching your ear is not a practice. Bricklaying, teaching, playing football, and brain surgery are.1

Perhaps the most common way this is characterized—what we call the Received View—is that when people engage in an activity, they articulate the situation that confronts them as a particular kind of problem, after which they apply the relevant knowledge (including rules, procedures, and so on) that enable them to solve the problem. In this view, the knowledge people hold in their heads enables the activities that lead to the resolution of the problem. Thus, it is commonly said that knowledge is applied in practice. Professionals can be distinguished from lay people in that they have acquired through training a body of tested and proven specialized knowledge that enables them to resolve problems in their given field (an ability typically beyond the reach of those who are not professionals in that field). So, for example, an administrator in a child care office is understood to use her specialized training in social work, child services, and family law, to deal with the complex issues of a neglected child in a dysfunctional family.

But neither is the reality of experience always that simple nor as we well know is the model of practice as applied specialized knowledge sufficient to account for all that social theorists and social scientists have come to find important about understanding, assessing, and improving practice. It is our aim in this article to address this gap, in no small measure by reconceptualizing the relationship between knowledge and practice.

Why do we need such a reconceptualization in the first place? Clearly, we are all practitioners of some competence in one field or another and we are well aware how our understanding derives from our practical doings in world. This point has been very well made by authors in various fields. For example, Greg Stolcis (2004), an experienced administrator, in an article argues for the primacy of practitioner experience in public administration, writes: “(Our experiences) are an accumulations of jobs we have performed, tasks we have accomplished, roles we have assumed, skills we have acquired, and decisions (and the resulting consequences!) we have made” (p. 364). So, why belabor the obvious? The answer is that precisely because we are competent practitioners, we assume that the relationship between knowledge and practice is obvious and clear. We intuit it, yet we often do so without having a clear understanding of exactly how knowledge and practice mutually shape each other and enable us to move about effectively in a world of uncertainty and complexity. Stolcis (2004), for example, continues his observation by saying: “(E)perience is active and engaged participation in events or activities that lead to the accumulation of applicable knowledge and skills.” This is beautifully put, but nowhere does he specify how active participation results in knowledge. This has typically been taken for granted.

But isn’t it the whole point of practice that we don’t need such an intellectual understanding to perform some skilled activity? In fact, the common genre in practice writing is to present a case and point out its actionable features (situatedness, interaction, embodied values, the flow of action, narrative, background knowledge, and so on) that enable the actors to bring the situation to a satisfying conclusion.2 Numerous writings have brought us valuable insights into the importance of practice and have done a great deal to erode the Received View of practice as explicable wholly in terms of applied knowledge. However, our understanding of how exactly practice, as a distinct phenomenon, generates knowledge and how knowledge functions within practice is underdeveloped. That is, the fact that part of what we know is generated in the course of practice is now well-documented; however, the various theoretical accounts of why this is the case is yet to be generally accepted by scholars, including within public administration and public policy analysis.3 Accordingly, we argue in this article that it is useful to unpack the relationships among knowing, practice, and context in a way that explicitly addresses such questions. Most practice is a complex blend of what we know brought to bear on situations that require skillful acting—situations that need to be sustained or improved. To approach such situations, for example, as calling only for knowledge (practically applied) or as entailing acting construed simply as intuitive (with some knowledge tacked on), too often fails to shed light on the issues these questions point to.

To explore the relationships among acting, knowing, and context, we have divided the article in two parts. The first half of the article is a rough chronology of the successive adaptations of the Received View of practice as applied knowledge. These adaptations gradually brought the Received View more in accordance with the practice-oriented critique in social theory and research of recent years. We will show that these adaptations are important, but argue that they fall short of offering a satisfying theoretical account that explains the relationship of practice, knowledge, and context. In fact, these adaptations do not enable us to show, as we wish to do, how knowledge and context can be explained in terms of—and are evoked within—practice, and not the other way round—and that this transpires within real worlds each of which has its own unique constraints and affordances, histories, and futures. In the second half of the article, we pick up on what we think is an essential element needed in the reformulation of the Received View: a relational conception of practice, knowledge, and context in which practice is distinct and primary. To develop this aspect of practice theory, we make use of some key concepts from modern Japanese philosophy. To our mind, the nondualist posture of Japanese philosophy gives rise to a provocative and useful conceptualization of the dynamic and fluid relationships among practice, the characteristics of the situation at hand, and the epistemic elements of practice itself. And it does so in ways largely missed by much Western philosophy. In this final section, we introduce three concepts that help capture this dynamic, relational understanding of practice: “actionable understanding,” “ongoing business,” and “the eternally unfolding present.”

Let’s, in conformance with the genre, anchor our argument in an example. For two reasons we have chosen an example from public administration. First, public administration (similar to planning and public policy) is a profession par excellence where issues of action, value, knowledge, and personal engagement are entangled in answering the ever present question: What is the right thing to do in this situation? (Wagenaar, 2004)4 Second, although there is a small but important literature that aims to acknowledge public administration’s inherently actionable, value-laden character from a pragmatist perspective, much of the doctrine and theory of public administration is deeply affected by the Cartesian conception of certain, procedurally and analytically derived, knowledge (Evans, 2000; Harmon, 2006; Miller, 2004; Shields, 2003, 2004, 2005, 2008; Stolcis, 2004).5

What follows is a protocol of an actual conversation between a department head and a detective in an urban police vice squad in a mid-size town in the Netherlands (we will return to this example later in this article). The conversation concerns how to classify and file a new case that has just come in.

sec.p: What is going on in this conversation may very well seem confusing—and not only to those conducting it. And the primary tool the Received View, the contention that practice is applied knowledge, offers little help in resolving the confusion or accounting for what the department head and the detective in fact accomplish in the exchange (Figure 1). Typically, a diagnosis of such a conversation from the Received View would identify a need for more knowledge to resolve the confusion and enable effective practice. This could include knowledge about the actual situation, the relevant administrative procedures, the scope and aims of enabling policy mandates, and so on. More knowledge is also frequently identified as necessary for better policy implementation, evaluation, and redrafting (one could even imagine a consultant suggesting the introduction of a computerized case-tracking system and “knowledge base” in this situation). However, such knowledge is not always easy or possible to get, and when got, seems often to leave important parts of the world underilluminated and the route to effective practice obscure.

sec.p: Figure 2 below represents the relationship between knowledge and practice at the core of the Received View. Admittedly, this is a simplified rendition of the dense and tricky relationship between knowledge and practice. For this reason, it would be easy to dismiss it as a straw man. Yet, this schematic view runs deeper than is usually appreciated, so it is worthwhile to consider some of its implications, including its rather considerable hold over both our institutionalized ways of managing society and our self-image as free, rational agents. We refer to this as the Received View because, although (as we sketch out below) it has been substantially challenged and augmented over the last two decades or so, the conception of professional practice as applied specialized knowledge still deeply informs such things as the curricula of our professional schools, the rhetoric of organizational management, the logic of information technology and knowledge management, prevalent doctrine about conducting legitimate and productive scientific research, the self-image of the people working in the complex and networked organizations through which we deal with collective problems, the form and logic of representative democracy, and a particular view of modern, liberal society. All are tied to the basic position that we master the world by acquiring knowledge of it and applying that knowledge within the constraints of given contexts. This is not the place fully (or even adequately) to explore these manifold connections.6 But they need to be noted to prevent a too hasty rejection of our schematic outline of the Received View as merely old hat and no longer worthy of serious attention.

A central reason for the tenaciousness of the applied knowledge conception of practical work and the many institutionalized ways of imagining, perceiving, organizing, and managing knowledge in our society, is that it substantially rests on a particular epistemology, one that has taken as almost self-evident a particular understanding of how we acquire and account for knowledge of the world around us. This epistemology is the well-known Cartesian epistemology of representation. It states that under certain felicitous conditions we can regard our knowledge as being a valid and reliable representation of external reality. These conditions entail performing certain formal, logical operations on the knowledge we posses so that the knowledge thus filtered is not contaminated by such threats to veracity as the effects of passion, emotion, the vagaries of our senses, or doctrinal bias. Knowledge thus understood, legitimizes our dealings with the world. In fact, in the Cartesian view, knowledge is seen as a guarantee of a proper understanding of the world, and in this sense stands in an hierarchical relation to practice and social interaction, it is understood as historically and ontologically prior to practice—in particular, our knowledge of the world enables us to act on it.7

This has proven to be a broadly persuasive and influential understanding of the place of knowledge in human action. In fact, this is why we feel comfortable speaking of the Received View, as it is not just epistemology, but a powerful, all-encompassing moral-institutional epistemological complex that governs our mastery of the world and how we can and ought to act effectively and responsibly within it. Indeed, in our day it has largely crowded out other ways of relating to the word so substantially, that, although we may commonly draw on those other ways informally, we still resort to Cartesian epistemology as the grand narrative that explains what we have been doing, or at least, should have been doing. In fact, much of modern thought has not only been subject to the privileging of the Cartesian epistemology, but, as Charles Taylor has suggested (Taylor, 1995b), it has also been epistemology-centered—that is, it has tended to privilege knowledge of the world (especially understood in Cartesian terms) as the primary mode of relating to it. Like Taylor, many social theorists and social scientists have increasingly found it necessary to ask what this Received View leaves out. As Figure 2 shows, practice is taken to be an empty box, as the subsequent application of prior knowledge. In the Received View, practice is enabled by the elements of knowledge, but it makes no contribution of its own to the conduct of everyday professional (or ordinary) life. In this fundamental sense, everything that is important to understand about professional practice ultimately can be accounted for in terms of the knowledge that enables it.

sec.title: Reframing Epistemology
sec.p: In better understanding the dominance of the Received View, we find it helpful to review some of the contemporary theoretical challenges to it. This in turn helps us frame our call for a reconceptualization of the relationship between knowledge and practice.

A number of contemporary philosophers and social theorists—including Heidegger, Dewey, Wittgenstein, Merleau-Ponty, Gadamer, Polanyi, Vickers, and Taylor—have, in different ways and with different emphases, challenged the dominant position of both Cartesian epistemology and epistemology itself. In rough outline, their argument is that formal knowledge emerges out of, and cannot be seen apart from, an often unacknowledged and largely tacit context of hunches, cues, bodily predispositions, expectations, appreciations, values, affects, and so on. That is, all knowledge, including formal knowledge, is embedded in ordinary experience, and, in an essential sense, gets its meaning, its life, from it. Traditional epistemology’s characterization of knowledge as explicit, objective, disengaged, universal, wholly transparent, and necessarily prior to practice (a set of characteristics that we summarize with the term formal), an ideal of knowledge that finds its most elevated expression in scientifically derived knowledge, is actually embedded in a “prior ontology of engaged, embodied agency” (Abbey, 2000). All knowledge, such philosophers and social theorists argue, is necessarily bound to a certain perspective or “form-of-life.”

This is not a plea for relativism—after all, dealing with conflicting positions or “second opinions” is a commonly noted feature of practice—but instead a plea for acknowledging the fullness of life (the “surfeit of reality” as Gadamer calls it) that is the source and context of our engagement with the world as competent agents. Rather, this stance argues against the claim that knowledge is able to severe its bonds with its intrinsic experiential and embodied contexts within which alone what we know is acquired and deployed. That is, traditional epistemology, with its prescriptions for rightness and truth that have symbolized its claim to the privileged status of formal knowledge, seems no longer to have a viable claim to that privilege. So, to “overcome epistemology,” as Taylor puts it (Taylor, 1995), is to reacknowledge and revalue the experiential and contextual sources within which knowing is always embedded.

Given the force of this philosophical plea for overcoming epistemology, our subtitle—“toward and epistemology of practice”—might look somewhat anachronistic. Our aim, however, is, while we retain the concept of epistemology, to give it a wider meaning that is better in tune with the more inclusive conception of knowledge and experience that emerged in 20th-century philosophy and social theory. Accordingly, by “epistemology” we mean “ the sub-discipline of philosophy devoted to questions of knowledge and justification” (Smith, 1997), with two important caveats. First, we do not take “knowledge” in the narrow scientistic sense of the Received View, but in a way that is inclusive of embodied, engaged, contextualized agency. Second, in the spirit of Taylor’s critique, we do not ascribe to epistemology the status of exclusive guardian of the foundations of effective and responsible understanding of and interaction with the world. Thus, we see an epistemology of practice as an inquiry into the possibilities and constraints of being engaged, embodied, contextualized agents.8

In what follows, therefore, we explore an understanding of the relationship between knowledge and practice that aims to avoid the conceptual and linguistic predilections of the Received View.9 Although we wish in particular to escape the trap of privileging knowledge, we feel that a viable understanding of practice, and how knowledge derives from acting, needs to address some of the questions that have traditionally been handled—or claimed—by epistemology. In particular, we want to avoid the so-what reaction that threatens treatises on practice: Yes, you have shown that action plays a role in our moving about in the world, but how does that help us understand how we attain reliable knowledge of the world? Our aim in this article is not only to show the indispensability of action for knowing and navigating the world, but also that the traditional knowledge–action dichotomy is a false one—and, thus, the so-what question, in our view, is misguided. Consequently, our aim is to contribute to the development of the practice perspective by treating “knowledge” in terms of what we call “the epistemic dimension of practice.” Another way of putting the central focus of this article, then, is, How do we better understand what is entailed in the epistemic dimension of practice? This leads us to introduce the concepts of actionable understanding, ongoing business, and eternally unfolding present as first steps in breaking out of the hold that the Received View has on the prevailing understanding of the relationship between knowledge and practice. In doing so, we first turn to an exploration of how the Received View has been modified in the face of recent challenges to it, and outline how we see these modifications as positive but ultimately inadequate.

sec.title: Modifications of the Received View: Reconceptualizing Context and Practice
A Role for Context
sec.p: One important augmentation of the Received View to emerge over the last 20 to 30 years is assessing the context of practice as an essential element in understanding the work of professionals. As the vice squad example above suggests, administrators and other practitioners do not work in a vacuum. The context of their work influences the way they go about doing their work. If we stick with administrators, this insight was articulated persuasively by Jeffrey Prottas and Mike Lipsky who have shown how the particular context of public service work (underfunded agencies, excessive case loads, difficult clients, structural difficulties in managing public service delivery), resulted in various strategies of accommodation. “Street-level bureaucrats,” as these administrators have come to be called, do not slavishly follow rules, but have a measure of discretion in shaping their activities that allows them to make the work bearable and effective given the circumstances—and effective in ways that can rarely be explained solely in terms of applying professional knowledge (Lipsky, 1980; Maynard-Moody & Musheno, 2003; Prottas, 1979). Similarly, work on rule application in the sociology of law, has shown different patterns or styles of rule application that are clearly tied to the organizational context in which an administrator workers works (Kagan, 1978). In other words, context matters, in that it constrains and even shapes practice. Practitioners cannot neglect or go around certain elements of their immediate physical, social, or policy environments that often stand before them as more or less immutable. In addition to the knowledge they bring to bear on the situation at hand, practitioners also take constraints or opportunities in the environment of their work into account in shaping effective action. Taken together, knowledge and context both impact on the way that practitioners (and ordinary people) go about addressing everyday situations. We have summarized this in Figure 3.

caption.p: The Received View: A role for context

sec.p: Although this augmentation of the Received View is extremely important, it still is widely treated in ways that can be seen as resting on the same Cartesian epistemology. Practice is still taken to be an empty box contributing nothing important or unique in its own right. All elements of practice, by this augmented view, can be accounted for in terms of knowledge plus context: we need practice to put knowledge to work within the constraints and affordances of a given context. Yet, anything that transpires in practice that might not be readily explained as an aspect of knowledge or context is treated as no more than the likes of intuition—a random factor viewed at best as necessary to close the knowledge–context–practice equation, and at worst as a threat to the ideal of good, reliable knowledge.

More broadly, this amended epistemological stance reflects little more than an illustration of the firm grip that the Received View, for all its seeming simplicity, has on our understanding of self and society. An upshot is that, as we saw earlier, the representational view of knowledge is, quite literally, at the center of a great many institutions that, taken together, are considered central to modern, rational society. An appreciation of the institutionalized implications and assumptions of the Received View, allows us better to understand the significant change along all these dimensions that is implied by the approach to practice we wish to develop here. But before we turn to what we will call the Practice Perspective, we need to discuss another important modification of the Received View that takes some of the criticism that has been leveled at it so far into account.

sec.title: A Role for Practice
sec.p: Another obvious way to improve on the Received View is to allow for the reciprocal influence of practice on knowledge and context (see Figure 4). Here, knowledge still tends to be privileged in understanding how we act in the world. The difference, however, is the realization that, in the application of knowledge in a given context, practice has the ability to confirm or modify both knowledge and context.10 Let’s unpack this statement.

caption.p: The Received View: A role for practice

sec.p: On the knowledge side of the equation, this makes intuitive sense. As most are ready to admit, our understanding of the world, as exemplified in our knowledge of it is almost always incomplete and sometimes ineffective. By applying it, we expose it to more aspects of empirical reality. This can add to or change or confirm what we know, and thereby we become more experienced, more seasoned, more effective practitioners. We also know that such learning can only be attained by engaging in the actual practice. It is not always (and in some cases, rarely) something that can be learned by reading books and manuals or by going to training sessions. Although to become a physician, one has to master the basic principles of physiology, pharmacology, and so on, to become a functionally competent physician, one has to apply this abstract knowledge in the actual practice of diagnosing, prescribing treatment, observing effects, and so on (this is in itself a complex statement, to which we shall return later). One has to see these principles in action, as it were.11

This has become more widely recognized by adherents of the Received View and institutionalized, for example, in the mandatory period of practical training that is an element of the curricula of professional programs. But again, the implications of this seemingly small adjustment to the model run much deeper than might at first blush be surmised. That is, this move claims, at least implicitly, that practice itself makes a distinct, autonomous contribution to the knowledge–context nexus. Practice leaves its own fingerprints on the things we know and the contexts within which we act. It is no longer a mere derivative of knowledge enacted within context. This means that we have to ask ourselves some important questions. What does this autonomous contribution of practice amount to? In particular, how is it a distinct contribution that cannot be reduced to either the application of knowledge or the constraints and affordances of a context? What is it that practice contributes, both to knowledge and to context? How does practice influence or modify knowledge and context? What does this mean for the way we conceptualize the relationship among knowledge, practice, and context? How do we assess, understand, and get about in the world when practice is an autonomous force in itself? Ultimately, our attempt to address such questions will lead us to reject the Received View and begin to formulate an epistemology rooted in practice.

But even if we remain within the confines of this modification of the Received View, we can begin to answer some of these questions. The influence of practice on knowledge is, in a way, the easiest to grasp. Knowledge is a human artifact. Although it is constrained by empirical reality, it acquires its status as knowledge through careful and systematic operations of the initial impressions of our senses, not, as we saw, by being a naïve reflection of what is “out there.” These careful and systematic operations are necessary because people are fallible in their grasp of reality. They are easily swayed by presumptions, prejudice, passions, and bias. The logical operations of the mind are necessary instruments in combating this fallibility. It is the operational nature of knowledge generation that gives it validity and certainty. Knowledge is au fond a reflexive act (Taylor, 1995b, p. 4). To engage in practice is in a way to expose the fruits of these operations once more to empirical reality, and where they are proven to be deficient, to modify and improve them.12

In the reciprocal modification, we see how practice comes to engage knowledge. An enduringly important contribution to the broader understanding of the relationship between knowledge and practice is Michael Polanyi’s famous distinction between “tacit knowledge” and “explicit knowledge” (Polanyi, 1962). For Polanyi, tacit knowledge is what we know but cannot say, particularly knowledge that is tied up with things we do. A classic example is riding a bicycle. Very few riders can say which way to turn the handlebars to stay upright or to prevent a fall. In fact, if asked, many say “I don’t know.” Yet, by definition, if one can ride a bike one must know how to turn the handlebars to keep upright—it is part of what knowing how to ride a bicycle means. For most riders, then, knowing which way to turn the handlebars is something they know but cannot say—that is, it is “tacit knowledge.” A parallel bit of explicit knowledge in this case would be something like “to keep your balance on a bike, always turn in the direction of a fall.” This we can say, thus as knowledge is explicit. It is commonplace at the very least that the expertise of practitioners entails a good deal of knowledge that cannot be made explicit.

It needs to be noted further that tacit and explicit knowledge are two distinct kinds of knowledge (or, as Polanyi often puts it, two dimensions of knowledge). Tacit knowledge, for example, is not knowledge that has yet to be (or needs to be) made explicit (and vice versa). Each does work the other cannot. A person who has not learned to ride a bike cannot be told “always turn into a fall” and thereby acquire the ability to stay upright: he or she must also acquire the tacit knowledge involved. Neither, as we have noted, does tacitly knowing how to ride enable one to say explicitly which way to turn the handlebars.

It also follows from their distinct character that one kind of knowledge cannot be turned into the other. Although resources of time, talent, and money are commonly put behind the notion that tacit knowledge can and must be made explicit to be useful, assessed, or improved (this has been a common theme, for example, in IT and “knowledge management”), this is a conceptual and operational mistake. There is no operation that can be performed on one kind of knowledge that will turn it into the other. Each kind can, however, be used as a tool to help leverage or generate the other. Although riding a bike, for example, one can use the tacit knowledge of keeping balance in ways that can help one discover explicitly which way the handlebars are to turn to avoid a fall—that is, one can use tacit knowledge and the activity of bike riding as tools to generate the explicit knowledge. Likewise, a novice bike rider might find the explicit knowledge that one turns into a fall as a useful aid in trying to acquire the tacit knowledge of remaining upright.13

Polanyi’s distinction between tacit and explicit knowledge is commonly paralleled with the distinction drawn by Gilbert Ryle between “knowing-how” and “knowing-that” (Ryle, 1949/2009). We contend, however, that these two important sets of distinctions are themselves distinct and that it can be useful to make their differences clear. For Ryle, “knowing-that,” in its most central sense, refers to things we can express in propositions whose truth or falsity can be tested. If someone says “I know that Carnegie Hall is on West 57th Street,” that claim can be checked to see if it is correct. Knowledge of this sort is “knowing-that.” The claim “I know how to ride a bicycle,” can also be checked to see if it is true or false by seeing what happens when a person gets on a bike. Yet the things one knows that enable him or her to ride are not expressible in the way examples of “knowing-that” are and do not lend themselves to tests of true or false. What we know in this way Ryle calls “knowing-how.” Moreover, Ryle claims, “knowing-how” is acquired over time, whereas “knowing-that” can be grasped at once. We contend, however, that it is a mistake to conflate “knowing-how” with “tacit knowledge” or “knowing-that” with “explicit knowledge.” Specifically, we would argue that “knowing-how” and “knowing-that” can each entail both tacit and explicit knowledge (and we believe there are instances of “knowing-that” which are necessarily acquired over time).14

Polanyi and Ryle’s distinctions have proven to be useful and provocative concepts in developing a better assessment of the relationship between knowledge and practice. We would hope that the four forms of knowledge we have presented here, drawing on Polanyi and Ryle, will also prove of some value. There continues to be much to learn concerning how these concepts might enrich our understanding of expertise and professional practice. We would observe, nonetheless, that all this has yet to escape the pull of the Received View. Indeed, the distinction between tacit and explicit knowledge and that between knowing-how and knowing-that have repeatedly been treated as prior to and enabling of practice. The importance of their challenge to the Received View should not be underestimated, but the fact that they have also been broadly incorporated into contemporary versions of the Received View cannot be ignored. Ultimately, we would aim to treat both sets of distinctions, (along with the fourfold combinations of them we offer in Note 14), as tools of practice, as things that come after and are made possible by practice—that is, as part of the epistemic dimension of practice.

However, the reciprocal modification of the Received View argues for the mutual influence of practice on knowledge and context. We have seen how practice influences knowledge, but how does practice influence context, as context by definition is something outside of us, something that is always to one degree or another both beyond and within our control? (In the most basic sense, we can modify what we know by reflecting on it; but reflection alone cannot, it might seem, modify context.) Our interaction with a given context, however, encounters the texture of that context, allowing for certain courses of action while restraining or preventing others. The extreme case of resistance, of course, is immutability. There are times when the world won’t budge. It contains rocks against which we bump our head, hot surfaces that threaten to burn us, or in the social world, laws and other institutional fixtures that forbid (or punish) certain actions. Context clearly informs practice. By its very nature it is more or less difficult to alter or modify by the swift and fleeting nature of practice. A rock can bruise our head, but not vice versa. Yet only practice acting through elements of context can change context. Rocks can crumble rocks, heat can melt them, and pressure can change natural elements into rock. By definition, context is self-possessive.15

It is precisely this position that has been fundamentally challenged in a most interesting and fruitful way by practice theorists in recent years. This has been a challenge that has led to a radically altered notion of the relation between agency and structure. But along with these broader theoretical moves, there are also simple, intuitively easy ways to appreciate how practice can modify external context that stay within the assumptions of the (modified) Received View. Take cooking, for example. Every experienced cook has organized his or her kitchen in such a way that the space and the tools are within easy reach or sequence. One can find one’s tools blindly in the middle of preparing a particular dish. This will do for the repertoire of cooking that he or she usually engages in. However, when one decides to embark on a new cuisine, it is quite likely one will have to rearrange the space and the tool set-up in way that accommodates the practical demands of that style of cooking. One has, in other words, modified the external context of one’s cooking practices. The parallel may be said with respect to other examples of work contexts.

sec.title: Knowing in Context
sec.p: Even this modified view of the knowledge–practice–context relationship leaves out important elements. It still tends to privilege knowledge as the appropriate mode of grasping what goes on around us, as the engine that drives our dealings with the world. In doing so, it rejects as noise or as irrelevant epiphenomena, much that persistently accompanies our attempts to find our way in the everyday world. For example, on an experiential level, doing things in the world (including engaging in a practice) seems often less a matter of applying bits of knowledge and more a matter of a continuous, ongoing stream of activity (Bourdieu, 1973). Often there is something that feels automatic and natural in such activities—even (or especially) in the case of embodiment, as if the body engages in the action in a somewhat autonomous way, uncoupled from our conscious thought. We do things “without thinking.” In fact, as we have all no doubt experienced, thinking about them can interrupt or disable the flow of action (playing piano or using a lathe might be good exemplars of this point). Very often, practice has an unplanned, improvisational quality that can be essential to understanding and carrying out effective practice.

In another sense, the received epistemological view provides little if any means to account for values that can stimulate professional activities, guide them as they unfold, and that supply a kind of measuring stick by which we can judge whether we should continue, stop, or redirect our actions or gauge success (Cook & Brown, 1999; Schein, 2004).16 It also leaves out the interactive nature of much practical work. Almost everything a practitioner does is done with—and made possible by—interaction. To accomplish something, we often interact with things, with material artifacts that we manipulate or act on according to more or less explicit expectations of what our actions will bring about. Inevitably, the objects “talk back,” at times defying our expectations and forcing us to adapt our assumptions about the characteristics of the objects, the nature of our interventions, or both. We also interact with people—especially people who are experienced in a particular field of practice, whereby the process of interaction seems to contribute something essential to finding our way into and about that given world. Knowing in the world is a joint experience (Shields, 2003; Wagenaar, 2004). The Received View, however, drives us into an image of individuals who, in splendid isolation, turn over bits of knowledge in their heads until, one hopes, it all pans out. Finally, it leaves out the massive, largely tacit body of understandings, memories, expectations, and routines that, together, inform the essential context of our actions.

Differently put, the epistemological view of our grasp of the world has emerged as peculiarly impoverished. Obviously, knowledge, as the collected, solidified, and systematized remnants of earlier experiences, does play an important role in how we grasp the world, but by putting knowledge forward as the major, privileged, or exclusive way of relating to the world, we overload it. We leave out the whole living, experiencing, interacting, embedding material and social environment that often gives rise to what we know in the first place and without which it simply wouldn’t make sense to us. It forgets—and in fact dismisses as irrelevant—the fact that knowledge is at all times embedded in a particular practical context, and emerges from our active engagement with some particular slice of the world (as Stolcis so beautifully puts it, as noted earlier on in this article). The explicit, universal knowledge of the Received View has come to seem far too narrow a bridge between self and world.

The particular practice or activity theory formulated by Jean Lave and her collaborators in the late 1980s and early 1990s can, in an important way, be taken as an explicit move to formulate an alternative to the Received View. Interestingly enough, it uses context as a lever to reconceptualize the knowledge–practice–context nexus. Lave argues that while it is by now a common and well-accepted insight that human action is indexical, that is, situated in and directed toward a material and social world, much less attention has been given to the conceptualization of the relations between the persons acting and the surrounding world (see for example, Wenger 1998, p. 53). In general, this relation is described either in deterministic terms (context as a rigid container that causes human behavior, yet is untouched by the influence of human actions), or in subjectivist terms (the ethnomethodological view of contexts as interpersonal constructions, that arise out of human interaction). Lave has summarized this dilemma with the felicitous phrase, “One has system without individual experience, the other experience without system” (Lave, 1988, p. 150).

In addressing this dilemma, Lave and others have focused on the social. They treat context as a “social world constituted in relations with persons acting” (Lave, 1993, p. 5). In other words, this reframes the concept of context. Instead of it being a fixed container, it now is seen as a dynamically integrated system of relations. To denote the relational conception of context, Lave uses the term setting. It signifies both the active, ongoing relationship that the actor maintains between herself and her environment, and the fact that this relationship is driven by the particular intentions and understandings of the individual as they emanate from the task that she engages in. Instead of passively reacting to the constraints of a particular context, the term setting suggests that the actor purposively seeks out those elements of her environment that are relevant to the task at hand. In this sense the actor “negotiates” her environment.17 Thus, actors and their world stand in a purposeful, dialectical relationship with each other. In trying to solve problems that come up in the course of their everyday work, they improvise with the material, social, and experiential resources at hand. Dialectical means here that problem and solution are not given, but bring each other into being in the process of acting on the world.18

sec.title: Knowledge, Context, and Practice as Mutually Constitutive
sec.p: We depict this understanding of the relationships among context, practice, and knowing in Figure 5. There are things that are characteristics of our interactions with the world, not just properties “out there.” For example, cold is neither a property of the world or of the self, it comes into being only in the interaction of the two: there is cold only when we interact with the world. Something similar might be said for knowing and context: for us, they only have ontological status when and to the extent that we interact with them in practice.

Yet, there is a sense in which even this is too narrow. Context, used here as “setting” also has an inherently systematic character. The elements of a given kind of context (physical, social, cultural, policy, organizational, and so on) do not and cannot be simply thrown together randomly. Rather, a context’s elements are related to one another systematically. Its systematic character is, in fact, how a context is constituted, how we identify it as distinct from other contexts or from an indistinct amorphous background; it is how we recognize that we are at the office rather than in a golf game, in a conversation rather than a chorus. When we interact with a context, its systematic character gives shape to our actions. That is, a context’s form informs practice. The form of a given context affords some practices while constraining others (there are things we can and cannot enact in a workshop, others in a board meeting). Just as cold arises in our interaction with the world, so do the affordances and constraints of a context arise in our interactions with it.19

Similarly, knowledge also has a systematic character that informs what and how we know, and thus also how we act. Just as the term mythology can refer both to the study of myths and to the systematically related set of myths embraced by a given people, so do we wish the term epistemology to refer both to the study of knowledge and to the systematically related bits of knowledge of a given community and the patterned activities that give rise to them and imbue them with the particular sense or meaning that enables us to recognize them as relevant, usable knowledge in a given context.20 This is why a particular professional community, for example, accepts some things as legitimate knowledge while rejecting others: some things find a foothold within the systematic structure of their epistemology, others do not. Similarly, no bit of knowledge exists on its own; part of what it means for something to be knowledge (rather than a hypothesis, a bit of information, or just nonsense, and so on) is that it is a part of an epistemology. This point can be seen in some rather common sense examples. In learning a field or skill, for example, we often reach a point where we say “oh, this is too much to learn.” Yet it often turns out that it was not too much but too little: when we learn more, suddenly things “make sense” or “fall together.” What is going on in such instances, we contend, is a shift in the epistemology that makes possible a better organization of what is known, which makes new knowledge easier to “take in” and existing knowledge easier to draw on. That is, how the bits of knowledge are systematically organized changes. Similarly, sometimes after things “fall together,” we discover that bits of knowledge we thought were essential suddenly appear useless. Such examples suggest that there are times when what we need is not more knowledge but a better epistemology.21 Such phenomena reflect the systemic character of knowledge.

There is more than an echo of Dewey here. This understanding of practice and knowledge as a form of purposeful, flexible engagement with the world clearly resonates with Dewey’s notion of “inquiry” or “productive inquiry.” Dewey saw “inquiry” not merely as a kind of cognitive, analytic reflection on the world, but as an active engagement with the world, or, to put it differently, as an active extending of what one knows beyond the immediate situation. His aim was to develop a unified account of doing and knowing in which inquiry is ongoing action in and on a situation that has become indeterminate by some sort of blockage or opportunity.22 As a result, routine action precipitates a restructuring of the original situation through cognitive, physical, and/or communal activities that ultimately bring about closure (even if temporary or provisional). Inquiry, or practice in our terms, is thus transformative. This is why Dewey often calls it “productive” inquiry: the result of such inquiry is a kind of closure made possible by productive restructuring of the original situation. A situation that is indeterminate has become whole again, at least temporarily (Burke, 1994; Dewey, 1920/1988; Strauss, 1993).23

Practice theory (in the formulation of such writers as Lave and Dewey) goes a long way in breaking down the dualism that is inherent in the Received View. With its emphasis on participation as an epistemic route into the world, and the inescapable indexicality of human action, such treatments of practice help provide important elements of a theory of practice. Practice is no longer a mere conduit for knowledge of the world; it is the vital element of knowing in the world. The knowing participant manages to move about in the everyday world in a sensible and effective manner because he or she is an actively engaged part of a world that is made one’s own.24 In particular, knowledge, practice, and context are no longer self-contained, closed boxes, but functional elements of one integrated system of activity, in which each allows for the others to contribute to the effective engagement with the everyday world. As we suggest in Figure 5, practice, knowledge, and context are mutually constitutive, with the broad, shaded arrows indicating the dynamic, ongoing character of this generative process.

Yet, we feel such theories, despite their many strengths and virtues, require (and help enable) us to push one step further. To see why and where, let’s focus on what many consider a main asset of a theory of practice. As we argued above, one of the major attractions of the Received View, one of the elements that most closely binds it to the institutions of modernity, is the promise of control. This promise resides in two closely linked forms: control over knowledge—through the formal operations in thinking that leads to certain, reliable knowledge uncontaminated by passion, bias, or prejudice—and, control over external reality—through the formal operations of scientific research and the innovation and deployment of technology. Tellingly, it is precisely on this issue that the Received View finds itself most vulnerable, and that practice theory can be further developed. First, empirically speaking, the quest for control has turned out to be far more elusive than either enlightenment thinkers, rationalists, or modern technologists had envisioned. The literature on this is now too extensive to be discussed in any detail here, but Merton’s (1936) notion of the “unintended consequences of concerted action,” Pressman and Wildavsky’s (1984) analysis of policy implementation as the “complexities of joint action,” Ulrich Beck’s (1992) concept of the “risk society,” and the emerging sciences of complexity (Urry, 2003; Waldrop, 1992) are sufficiently well-recognized to make the case for the necessarily limited reach of either form of control.25 The basic argument is that the well-known procedure of analytically breaking the object to be known and controlled down into its supposedly constitutive elements, and to proceed then by regrouping those elements into a working model of the object, the performance of which can then be gauged by changing the value of one or more of the constituent variables, is inherently deficient. It misses many of the interactions within the systems that produce the contingent, unforeseen outcomes that have dramatically compromised efforts of social engineering (Dryzek, 1990; Waldrop, 1992). Complexity makes for a contingent, unpredictable world, particularly the world of human affairs, in which certainty is often in short supply (Wagenaar, 2007). Meanwhile, we would note, simplicity, also, has proven to have pitfalls of its own). The best we can hope for is to harness uncertainty and complexity (and simplicity), aware that there are better and worse ways of doing this. We feel that any theory of knowledge, practice, and context must be able both to account for, and to deal effectively with, this fundamental aspect of reality.

The upshot is that a practice perspective has to answer two related challenges. First, it has to explain how people harness uncertainty, complexity, and the limits of predictability, when they extend their actions in ongoing time. This is a simple but deep requirement. The Received View has the central and almost always overlooked quality that it is retroactive: it explains how actors think and decide ex post facto. Once all the information on how a particular decision has run its course is in, we can exhaustively explain how that decision was made. Much policy analysis, for example, is of this kind.26 But actors live in a world where the outcome of decisions is generally not immediately or completely known, where problem formulations are unclear and fundamentally contested, where no one can oversee the implications of alternative courses of action, where, in short, the answer to the question “What to do?” is shrouded in fog.

This is a situation that no one can escape. It is our nature as human beings that we are always standing at the edge of the present, venturing into an uncertain future, guided by an ambiguous history of experience, convention, artifact, and habit—and empowered by a capacity, as dazzling as it is fallible, for imagining the unrealized and then judging what we ought to do and how best to do it. Within this inescapable present, we find ourselves bound, often inexplicably, to groups of bewildered fellow actors for whom our collective past seems as inevitable as our future is inscrutable. This is all we have. This is the human condition. Yet, in such a world, most actors have learned to move about routinely in ways that more often than not are effective and responsible. How do they do it? Differently put, a theory of practice has to be able to explain how actors arrive at effective and responsible courses of action with only limited information about the situation at hand and inherently fallible guesses about the future. It has to account for the strategies actors employ and the resources they use. In other words, it has to explain how we are able so often to go beyond what we already know and perceive.

A theory of practice must also address the constraining effects of history. As we saw, actors are locked inside a perspective—that of their own personality and experience, that of their group, and that of their milieu (nation, gender, historical period, and so on). Although these perspectives allow the actor to act, they also constrain him or her in interactions with others. This is the fundamental epistemic dilemma of perspectivism (Fay, 1996). Although we are dependent on our knowledge, experience, insights, values, and preferred solutions to find our way in the world, these also prevent us from grasping the full spectrum of knowledge, experience, insights, values, and solutions that are available in the human community. How, in knowing and moving in the world, can we overcome our confinement within our own horizon? The version of practice theory discussed here certainly suggest some ways to overcome the constraining effect of context by exploring how we move about effectively in a contingent, unpredictable world. But we feel that these challenges need to be addressed more explicitly or systematically.27

sec.title: From Epistemology to Practice: Turning Knowledge on its Head
sec.p: Taking our next step toward a practice perspective actually entails making a substantial shift. Specifically, we believe it means treating knowledge and context as aspects of practice—or more specifically, as artifacts of practice. In a sense, this shift turns the original formulation of the Received View on its head: rather than practice being seen as wholly explicable in terms of knowledge (or knowledge constrained by context) here, as suggested in Figure 6, we see practice as primary and knowledge, along with context, as calling for explication in its terms. Indeed, we wish to characterize knowledge as part of an epistemic dimension of practice, and the elements of context as artifacts of practice that constitute its social and physical worlds. In making this move, we introduce three interrelated concepts: “actionable understanding,” “ongoing business,” and “eternally unfolding present.” Accordingly, a central undertaking of professional practice is generating an understanding of a situation at hand that enables effective and responsible action within “ongoing business.” This “actionable understanding” is informed by a constantly renewed past, directed at an always partially decipherable future, and situated in a present that is “eternally unfolding.” Below, we explore these three aspects of the shift.

In developing these concepts, let us return for the moment to the vice squad example at the beginning of this article.28 We will then develop each concept making use of the example. The setting in which the vice squad’s work takes place is a small suite of offices that is part of a larger regional police station. The largest room contains desks for all of the detectives. The detectives take turns staffing a 24-hr hotline (the piket dienst in Dutch). There are terminals for accessing the information system, and places to store paperwork. The other rooms are much smaller and are used to interview victims and witnesses or to interrogate suspects. The unit consists of 10 detectives, some of whom are employed part-time. Each morning at 8:00, the detectives meet in a so-called work meeting to discuss the progress on cases that are under investigation and to assess and distribute the cases that came in that night.

sec.title: Actionable Understanding
sec.p: We have deliberately chosen an example that is conspicuously ordinary. This kind of exchange between public servants could have taken place in any office, in any country, on any particular day. The detectives need to move forward with their ordinary tasks of dealing with events and organizing work. Within that ongoing flow of activity, situations are encountered that impede what needs to be done and others that facilitate it. The matters that prompt discussion in this example involve the registration of an incoming case. The situation arises out of a routine task of the unit: how to keep track of the cases that come in and are in various stages of investigation. An examination of the nature of such cases will help sketch out an understanding of some of what is entailed in this part of the vice squad’s work.

In much of the world of public administration, a case is an elementary particle. It is the basic administrative unit, to which administrative actions and permutations are grafted. A case is also an empty placeholder that allows both the activities concerning individual clients and the organization of administrative work at the agency level. Additionally, a case has a physical substrate in the form of a paper or digital file. All this is true and nonproblematic, at the surface level. In reality, a case is a construction, or better, an enactment, an ongoing, joint achievement of a community of administrators.

In general terms, a “case” is an artifact of practice within the field of public administration, the product of a certain amount of administrative processing in support of various policy aims. It can be distinguished from the “raw” situation that initially comes to the attention of the vice squad. Some of these “raw” situations are not entered as cases because the detectives decide they do not merit investigation or they fall outside the jurisdiction of the unit. A lot rides on the decision to enter a particular situation as a case. Once a situation is designated as a case, the unit in fact enters into an implicit agreement with the outside world (victim, suspect, the DA, police superiors, the community) to work on the case in an effective and responsible manner. In other words, the administrative act of transforming a raw situation into a case creates a complex set of mutual expectations, rights, and responsibilities between the unit and the outside world. For example, victims and their families may expect to be treated with respect and sensitivity. Conversely, they are expected to be truthful about what has happened. Similarly, suspects have certain legal rights (e.g., the right to have a lawyer), but forfeit others, as when they are obliged to hand over any evidentiary materials relevant to the case (e.g., computers, clothes). Communities have a right to be informed about certain risks (as when a child molester is active in a neighborhood). And the formal registration of a case signals to the larger police organization that the vice squad has taken on itself the responsibility to handle the case in a professional, responsible, and timely manner, and to bring it to an appropriate end. This is what engagement amounts to: the active involvement of a professional organization with its environment.

In this way, this vice squad registers roughly 400 cases per year. Now, the act of registration per se, (creating an administrative artifact that has an entry in some system of registration) poses various challenges for the detectives. These may have to do with such things as the nature of sexual pathology or the demands of the police organization. For example, some of the situations that are transformed into cases involve identical persons (as in this instance). Such cases create boundaries that real world situations may not have. For example, the squad may register as a case under investigation the sexual abuse of an eldest daughter by her father. Some months later, a younger daughter calls the unit reporting that she has been regularly abused by her father and her uncle. Must this be registered as a separate case? In the raw situation, both instances of abuse are probably part of a pattern of pathological family relations, but the presence of an uncle in the second situation might warrant its registry as a separate case. This is a matter of the legal constraints and affordances of the unit’s work environment. The upshot here is that the seemingly neutral term register does not necessarily capture all the work that constitutes establishing a case—work, it should be noted, that is largely implicit and nested inside the workflow of the unit. Similarly, the term case does not necessarily capture the complex, multilayered, relational, practical, and moral configurations that are brought into being by the act of creating a case—which are themselves various kinds of constraints and affordances of the social, cultural, or policy contexts of this work.

For the detective and department head to register something as a case means they have formed an understanding of it that entails a number of things, including, making it an active, ongoing, and embedded part of their work, having it fall under various laws or policies applicable to the vice squad, addressing the possibility of it articulating with other public agencies (e.g., social services), and trusting that doing this is consistent with their often taken-for-granted sense of what is and what might be, of what is desirable, and what is to be avoided in such a situation, and to do all this in a way that enables them to take an appropriate action on it at an appropriate time—that is, an action that is effective and responsible given these sorts of contextual factors. This is an example of what we have come to call an actionable understanding. In this instance, the vice squad must develop a mutually held understanding of the case that enables them to take mutually acceptable action on it. Their chief job at this point, we argue, is not applying knowledge, but generating a form of practice, within which they very well may develop new knowledge or deploy existing knowledge. But it is the practice that is primary. Knowledge is a tool of it. The value of that knowledge lies in its utility within practice, not in a supposed ability to give rise to practice. To form such an actionable understanding clearly entails balancing many factors. And a sound accounting of what the members of the vice squad do must be explicable in terms of them. What the detectives know—or need to know—is only one of those factors, and thus it alone cannot account for what is done.

sec.title: Ongoing Business
sec.p: For the vice squad, the various dimensions of the challenge of registration—its practical topography—are not wholly pregiven by policy mandates or administrative rules, but only become clear as the trajectory of a case evolves. They emerge out of the ongoing business of the squad. To grasp the full dimension of everyday practice, it is important to elaborate on what we mean by the ongoing business. Several common terms give an initial suggestion as to what we mean by it: “business as usual,” the stable state,” the “ground” to the “figure” of challenge and opportunity. All these point to the practical work of these detectives, which consists of a flow of routine actions and understandings, a certain physical environment, a set of tools, the presence of colleagues who behave in predictable ways, and shared memories, meanings, and expectations, that, taken together, form the experiential environment of the unit. In other words, this is the stuff that is expected to be there, and which often merits no special attention. Ongoing business is part of the intersubjective landscape of the members of the work unit, and the embodied reality in which they operate.

We want to emphasize that, although ongoing business involves physical objects or artifacts such as tools, work procedures, and legal rules, these do not necessarily constitute a physically fixed or static structure. Ongoing business is made up of experience, shared by the members of the unit. Ongoing business is simultaneously tied to the experiences and activities of the detectives, yet also independent of them.29 That is, it exists independent of the presence of one or another individual detective, yet it could not exist outside the experiences of the squad as a whole. In that sense, ongoing business is a collective entity. As a collective possession, it is part of the body of experience of each individual member as he or she is socialized into the unit. Ongoing business is part of what makes a collection of individuals into a community. It is also what gives particular meaning or purpose to the activities that constitute the practice of that community.30

Also, ongoing business is, of course, dynamic. This comes from its experiential nature. As it continuously interacts with the world, it is continuously informed and influenced by what goes on in the world. Most events simply assert the ongoing business, thereby contributing to its stability, but some events may be perceived as a threat. For example, during the time this case was being observed, one of the detectives, who had been on pregnancy leave and was just returning to work, began to behave erratically, such as showing up late for work, or refusing to take on tasks. Part of the ongoing business of the unit is that detectives are always on time, do not hesitate to take on assigned tasks, (except when they are demonstrably overburdened; task assignment is more or less a collective decision that is discussed in the morning work meeting), and do not object when another detective asks to take over a task. These habits make it possible to navigate the fundamental unpredictability of the work, in terms of when cases come in, how many there are, and how the trajectory of the cases develops. Against this background, the erratic behavior of the detective was a tear in the fabric of the ongoing business. This led to a lot of discussion among the detectives, the central theme of which was a weighing of mutual solidarity against their anger at this violation of the unspoken rules of the work unit. In our terms, what was at stake was the integrity of the “ongoing business,” of the stable state that made the work of the unit possible. The discussion among the detectives of how to deal with the errant colleague was a rare occasion in which the ongoing business itself became a subject of reflection. What the detectives discussed among themselves was if the ongoing business should be adapted to include the temporary presence of an unreliable colleague or if its integrity should be maintained by removing the colleague.

The concept of ongoing business, then, points to a dynamic, developmental, often taken-for-granted and unproblematic background against which and within which problems and opportunities of community’s practice arise and are dealt with. For the vice squad, dealing with ongoing business is neither primarily a matter of applying knowledge nor is it fruitful for an observer to account for all that is going into ongoing business and the vital role it plays in the squad’s practice solely in terms of what can be known. Knowledge does not give rise to ongoing business, rather the practices of the squad, of which, ongoing business is an essential element, determine what knowledge is needed and how it is best deployed.

sec.title: The Eternally Unfolding Present
sec.p: In the dialogue from the vice squad case, we note that one thing that might be immediately apparent is that there is a discussion taking place in the present. To take this a step further, the dialogue is part of the practice of the detectives, and practice necessarily takes place in the present. In another sense, however, this may seem so obvious that it could easily be dismissed as a trivial observation. In fact, it is often taken for granted that what needs to be explained and/or what provides for explanation lie beyond what is immediately apparent. Many of our analytic traditions would incline us to say, “Sure, the detectives are talking. But to find out what’s really going on we need to dig below the surface.” Indeed, the familiar phrase “what’s really going on” is implicitly an ontological claim that the real stuff, the stuff with explanatory power, is of a different kind and that it lies elsewhere. As we have observed above, for example, the Received View’s accounts of practice tend to privilege explanations given in terms of knowledge seen as underlying and enabling practice. Although we do not at all wish to dismiss wholesale the value of “digging below the surface,” it has been our aim to question the predilection of privileging knowledge, or other foundational “essences,” in this way, especially as doing so tends to deny explanatory power to practice itself. In this spirit, we contend that as practice necessarily takes place in the present, the understanding of knowledge and context we are advancing must be based on this, not vice versa. In this spirit, it is within the immediate present of practice that we believe actionable understandings are formed and ongoing business is sustained. It is also there that we see knowledge and context taking on the form and meaning that constitute them as artifacts of practice. To sketch this out, we turn our attention briefly to matters of ontology.

The modern world has cultivated a dominant ontology that is intimately interconnected with the Cartesian epistemology sketched out above. Indeed, the two conceptually reinforce each other, and are pillars of the Received View. We need, therefore, to outline this ontology, identify how it supports Cartesian epistemology, and put forward an alternative ontology with some importantly different epistemic implications.

From the perspective of the dominant ontology, there exists an all-encompassing physical universe that behaves in ways captured by the observations and theories of the physical sciences. The past is the past of the universe, and the future is determined by its present state. We live in this universe, and, as physical beings, are part of it. From our inner lives, we peer out through the capacities of our senses and minds (which themselves may or may not be wholly physical) to grasp the nature of the universe and the patterns of its workings. Anything we might say about the outer world—anything we might claim to know—that is not in keeping with this ontology is, at least in theory, either illusion or poetry (as one 20th-century philosophical school was fond of saying).

Yet, as contemporary philosophers and social scientists have looked ever inward, ontology itself has come increasingly to look like a conceptual scheme for understanding our experience of the world, and less an account of the world itself. If ontology is a direct account of anything, it has been suggested, perhaps it is one of our inner experience of the world, not of the world outside us. And if this is so, then any knowledge associated with ontology might be less about the world (physical or social), and more about our experience of it.31 The patterns of the universe’s workings, after all, do not appear directly to us—whereas our consciousness of them does. Some have seen in this the danger of falling into a solipsistic trap. Consequently, a cottage industry in theories has sprouted up that purport to draw correspondences of various sorts between the patterns we find in our subjective experience and the way the world actually is. Although philosophers, physical scientists, and social scientists have struggled to perfect such theories, proof of any sort has remained stubbornly elusive. If we follow this path, at least one form of intellectual honesty brings us to the edge of an unbridgeable gap between a consciousness we have direct access to and an outer world we do not.32 In the face of such challenges, however, the Cartesian epistemology and its accompanying ontology have maintained a surprisingly tenacious grip on our understanding of ourselves and the world. At this point, these two contending sets of ontological and epistemological observations have come to form a seemingly incommensurable and irresolvable counterpoint—particularly to the extent that each seems often to claim that it contains the other. Indeed, this remains a key conundrum of contemporary thought.

One philosophical approach more in keeping with what we believe is the inescapable primacy of human experience, including ways we would relate to practice, can be found in the work of the major 20th-century Japanese philosopher Nishida Kitaro (Nishida, 1911/1990). A major project of Nishida’s was to address traditional questions of Western philosophy from the perspective of Eastern thought, especially Zen theory and practice. For Nishida, an ontology should rest first and always on consciousness, not on an outer physical world. Since, Nishida argued, the only thing we have direct access to, the only thing we “cannot even begin to doubt,” is consciousness, we ought to honor this fact and build our understanding of experience and of the world from that point.

In Nishida’s view, at the core of consciousness what we find is “nothingness.” One way of unpacking this claim—which may at first seem contradictory or obfuscatory—is to understand “nothingness” as “no-thing-ness.” That is, what we find at the core of our being, at the inescapable center of our consciousness, is not things but process or activity.33 All we are aware of comes and goes: a rock or the sun or a person enters our consciousness and then departs and is potentially different when it enters again.34 It is out of such occurrences within conscious experience, Nishida holds, that we create and unify our sense of the world, our thoughts, memories, intentions, and our selves. Looking inward, Nishida (like most modern physicists looking outward) reminds us that all “things” are really “events”. So the world around us and each of its constituent parts (including our memories of them), Nishida claims, are for us collections of experiences, or “systematic singularities” (to use his term), that we assemble to make sense of experiences within our consciousness (akin to what above we have called “artifacts”).

Following this, the constraints and affordances of the outer world only come to us through our experience of them. The world in which we live is made by us in interaction with those constraints and affordances. For us, then, the world exists in our interaction with it. This interactive character can be seen in the work of another 20th-century Japanese philosopher Watsuji Tetsuro. Watsuji held that what is commonly understood as the basic properties of the world are actually properties of our interaction with the world (Watsuji, 1935/1961). In fact, the example of cold given above comes from Watsuji. Cold, he argued, is not a property of the world, it is not just molecules moving at a given speed; nor it is just within us, because without the movement of molecules there is no experience of cold. Cold is a property of our interaction with the world, it arises and exists only within that interaction. So too, Watsuji insists, for much if not all of the elements of our experience of the world.35

In keeping with this ontological stance, Nishida holds that we exist always in the present—specifically, the present of consciousness. The past, in his view, is accessible only in the present; it is constantly assembled and reassembled as we move though time. Likewise, the future, for us, remains always a feature of our present imaginings (perhaps constrained by our ongoing reassembly of the past). Accordingly, we exist in what here we wish to call an eternally unfolding present where all is process. Even the myriad things of the world are “systematic singularities”—artifacts to the extent that we shape and/or give meaning to them in an ongoing way in our interaction with the world within the unfolding present.

This sketch of Nishida’s ontology leads us to his epistemology. What we might claim to know about our experience (that is, about ourselves and the world) is also an aspect of the workings of consciousness within the unfolding present. Knowledge, from Nishida’s perspective, is something we produce when we withdraw, to one degree or another, from active engagement with the world and reflect abstractly on that engagement. It is something we hold in that part of present consciousness we call memory, and which only has life when we use it to develop our understanding or to inform our actions as we return to fuller engagement with the world.36 The knowledge of a principle of physics, or a law regulating the rights of suspects, by this account, is a systematic singularity, evoked in the present consciousness of our ongoing memories. Such a systematic singularity is useful to make sense out of and/or to manipulate other systematic singularities, which are constructed in our conscious experience of particular constraints and affordances of the social or physical world.37
