We see the ontology and epistemology suggested by Nishida as helpful in moving from an understanding of knowledge as underlying and enabling practice to seeing practice itself as having an epistemic dimension—including seeing knowledge as an artifact of practice.38 If we are constantly within the eternally unfolding present, knowledge cannot be seen as something static, something that can be stored away so that later it can be retrieved, distributed, and shared.39 As our opening quote from Montaigne suggests, if we know something, we know it now. What we know is sustained, evoked, shaped and deployed only in the present. Beyond this, it has no reality for us, and thus no reality of its own. Conversely, since the eternally unfolding present is the only reality we have, it is only within that reality that what we know has any life. It is for this reason, in our view, that knowledge cannot be seen as enabling practice because practice is a necessary condition for knowledge, not the other way round. It is this sense of knowing—as evoked within our consciousness through engagement with the world within an eternally unfolding present— that we wish to capture by saying that practice has an epistemic dimension.

What we know indeed plays a role in how we act, how we engage the world, and how we give shape to the world through practice. It is tied up with what we do, but it is not something that comes before or underlies what we do. We may use a hammer in building a bookcase—it helps us interact with wood and nails, and it helps us give shape to the bookcase. But the hammer does not give rise to what we do. It maybe necessary in deploying our skills, but it alone does not produce those skills. It can be a valuable and, in some ways, necessary tool in the practice of building a bookcase. But it is the hammer that is an artifact of the practice of building a bookcase, not the practice that is a product of the artifact. Likewise, with knowledge: it is a valuable and necessary part of practice. But it is something that is evoked and deployed within and by way of what we do, not something that underlies and enables what we do. It is in this way that we see knowledge as an artifact of practice.

Just as our engagement with the world is informed in part by the epistemic dimension of practice (by what we know), it is also informed by the constraints and affordances that we encounter in our interactions with the physical and social world—that is, by context. As with “knowledge,” we also wish to see “context” as an artifact of practice. There is another concept in Nishida that helps us to do this. Nishida expresses the concept in the Japanese word basho (Nishida, 1933-1934/1970). In colloquial Japanese, the word basho generally means “place.” But as a concept in traditional Japanese culture and modern Japanese philosophy (and more recently Japanese social science),40 the term suggests much more.41 Nishida notes that everything that exists does so in a particular location (a basho), and the social and physical history embodied in a given basho make possible and inform the activities that take place within it (they also inform our identity).42 Conversely, who we are and what we do in a given basho sustain and shape the basho itself. For our purposes here, this suggests a “sense of a particular place,” one that both affords a particular kind of practice, and, in turn, is constituted by that practice.

A typical example of basho, to stay with the Japanese theme, is one from sumo wrestling. A sumo match takes place in a sumo ring. The ring is a particular place: it has a given size and configuration. The characteristics of the ring afford and constrain the practice of sumo—that is, without the ring, there cannot be a proper sumo match. The ring, meanwhile, is itself constituted by the rules and traditions of the practice. And in an important sense, the ring only really becomes the ring when it is in use, when it is affording the practice. Otherwise, it is little more than a circle on the floor. It is only within the unfolding present of a match that the ring affords practice, and it is only in affording practice that it is truly the ring, the basho, of sumo. Likewise, it is only when sumo wrestlers physically and mentally locate themselves within the ring—when they have a sense of that particular place—that they can meaningfully engage in the practice of sumo wrestling. The same would be true of a tennis court or a football pitch. This can also be said of the context of many forms of practice—from the example of the vice squad above, to the setup of a traditional lecture hall, to the design of an office, factory, laboratory, or workshop, and so on. The idea is that such a context both affords the particular practices that take place within it, and is itself informed by those practices. In our terms, the context of a practice—its basho—is itself an artifact of that practice: it derives its ongoing existence, form, and meaning from the practice it affords.

So, let’s return to our observation about the vice squad case. There is a discussion between the detective and the department head that is taking place in the present. The discussion is part of their practice, and practice (like all life) necessarily takes place within an eternally unfolding present. We take this present not simply as the temporal dimension of the case, but as the ontological setting within which practice occurs and knowledge and context are evoked. The dialogue proceeds like a tennis match: at each step of the dialogue, terms, ideas, concerns, and the like are volleyed back and forth until the parties are able to move on to the next step. At the beginning, the detective and the department head have exchanges about how the case is identified, in which various terms are used (“rape,” “checked it in the DPS [the information system]” “intake interview,” and so on). The focus shifts to how they should handle the case (giving it one or another “annotation,” putting it in “holding mode,” “delete the case completely,” and so on). There is also a concern about being able to locate the case properly in the future (“. . . when someone calls . . . how do we find out who has the case . . .”). Each comment seems to unfold from the previous one and lead to the next. All of these things are part of what the detectives know. It is within this unfolding dialogue (“unfolding present”) that what the detectives know is evoked, tested, modified, agreed on, and referenced to the future. How they ultimately deal with the case (annotate, put on hold, and so on) is generated within the dialogue. It is in this sense that we see their practice as having an epistemological dimension. Knowledge was not retrieved and applied in a way that enabled practice. Rather, within their ongoing practice, the detectives evoked various things they know about dealing with cases and used them as tools to generate an understanding of the case at hand that enabled them to move on to the next thing.

The detectives have various forms of tools at their disposal that enable and give particular character to their work. These include conventions like “intake interview,” physical infrastructure, such as the information system and the files, and concepts—including ones that have legal and policy aspects—such as “case.” These tools neither come to the detectives’ hands fully formed nor are they immune to change over time. Like Watsuji’s characterization of “cold,” such tools arise for the detectives in their interaction with them. It is within the detectives’ interaction with the social and physical world of their practice that these tools have their particular form and meaning. An “intake interview” does not exist except when it is enacted. The information system only has the functions it does to the extent that the detectives put it to use. “Case” does not sit on a shelf waiting to be deployed, but has function and meaning only when referred to or used in practice.

Similarly, the various things that make up the social and physical world of the detectives’ work are not fixtures of nature, but things that are created and sustained within their practice. They do not have fixed functions and meanings. Rather, their identity is constantly being evoked, deployed, and modified in what the detectives do. They are in that sense “systematic singularities” of the detectives’ practice. The specific meaning and use of the terms case and annotation in the dialogue, for example, are given their specific meaning and use by the detectives in the course of their conversation. In a larger sense, the theme running through the entire dialogue about how to deal with the case is an exercise in defining it as a systematic singularity. Various bits of its history, present state, and future are referenced and treated as meaningful parts of a single thing, a single case: it comes from the police in The Hague, it is found in the DPS [information system], it gets a particular annotation designating its present state, which, in turn, anticipates how it might be handled in the future. These are seen by the detectives not as isolated unrelated events, but are actively put together by them in the course of their conversation as a systematic singularity within their practice.43

In another sense, we can see “annotation,” “holding mode,” “delete the case completely,” and the like as artifacts of the detectives’ practice. At various points while the detectives talk with one another, they withdraw partially from direct engagement with the case to reflect on it. In doing so, they evoke systematic singularities like “holding mode” that aid in this reflection. Their discussion about how the case might be annotated, for example, drew both on memories of the term’s use in the past and on projections of how it might function in the future. In this part of the discussion, the form and meaning of “annotation” was augmented by its application to the case at hand—that is, it was further shaped as an artifact of the detectives practice. This process, in turn, helped the detectives form an understanding of the case that enabled them to move to the next step with it: “holding mode” and “annotation,” as forms of knowing, enabled the generation of an “actionable understanding.” What the detectives know is not static stuff that is stored away and later retrieved in a way that gives rise to practice. It is an artifact of practice that is shaped by the very practice that it aids.

Finally, the practice of the detectives is afforded, in part, by the social and physical world within which it transpires, by its context. The setup of the office, the infrastructure of the hot line and the information system, the laws and policies that apply to the vice squad, the traditions of the unit’s “ongoing business,” and so on are embodied in the particular place—the basho—of the vice squad’s practice. And the specific form and meaning that the elements of this basho have are, in turn, evoked, confirmed, and modified through their use within that practice. They are, in this sense, artifacts of the unit’s practice. For one of the detectives to engage in practice effectively, he or she must have a “sense of the particular place” within which he or she works. A detective must have, for example, an actionable understanding of “annotation” to use the term and its associated applications properly, in a way that the others in the unit can accept as appropriate (such an understanding is among the things that someone new to the unit would likely lack). Just as a familiarity with the rules and the court of tennis affords the game, so does a familiarity with the basho of the vice squad afford effective practice within it.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In recent years, what we have called the Received View has faced growing theoretical and empirical challenges. It is no longer secure to assume that knowledge necessarily precedes, underlies, and enables action. Yet typically the assumption that it does is at least implicit in such things as the design of research, consulting, education, and training programs, and in the drafting, implementation, and assessment of public policies. This is true to a greater degree than is generally appreciated or that the strength of the challenges might lead one to assume—and is indicative of the tenacious grip that the received view still has on us. For such reasons, more work needs to be done on the development of theoretical and practical alternatives to the Received View. Our aim here has been to make a contribution to this work.

It is our contention that one viable and potentially very valuable alternative is to “turn knowledge on its head”—to see practice as having an epistemological dimension, rather than seeing knowledge as giving rise to practice. In outlining this view, we have noted the growing sense that practice is not explicable solely in terms of what is known—or conversely, that practice is solely a matter of putting knowledge into action.44 We have noted as well the growing awareness of various ways in which practice is systematically shaped by the contexts within which it takes place—that practice responds to both the constraints and affordances of its native milieu. Even in traditional terms, work on such themes has, at the very least, begun convincingly to show that there are significant elements of practice that are not exhaustively explicable in terms of what is known.

Although noting the importance of such challenges to the Received View, we have argued that ultimately not all that goes on in practice can be explained solely in terms of knowledge and context. Indeed, we hold to the view that practice itself is not passive but active, and that among its active traits is that it gives shape to knowledge and context, that the contents of knowledge and context are accepted, sustained, and modified or rejected through practice. We have argued that this brings us to a point where practice and knowledge can be seen as mutually constitutive, as can practice and context.

At this conceptual juncture, it is our contention that a broader shift needs to be taken—specifically, that knowledge and context need to be seen as artifacts of practice. This includes seeing practice as having an epistemological dimension. We have argued that among the implications of this shift are three key concepts: actionable understanding, ongoing business, and the eternally unfolding present. This shift and the concepts it entails bear both on how we understand the relationship between knowledge and practice theoretically and on how that theory might help redesign applied efforts.

We believe that turning knowledge on its head deserves further exploration conceptually and in practice. There is need, for example, for the epistemological shift we have proposed to be expanded and tested. Systematic application to full case studies would be quite valuable. We ourselves are currently building on the insights from Japanese philosophy to develop a broader theoretical basis for the assessment of cases in public administration and technological innovation (in expanding the concept of actionable understanding, for example, to account for the epistemic dimension of networked human systems). Also, other epistemologies that do not assume that what we know must be placed ahead of what we do might be proposed (along with their accompanying ontologies, when needed) and assessed against what is outlined here. There are several applied areas where the concepts we propose might suggest redesign of traditional approaches. The standard model for training in corporations and public agencies, for example, rests firmly on the Received View: work stops, a period of training ensues (frequently offsite—that is, out of the basho), after which employees return to the workplace to put new knowledge into practice (not always with sterling success). Billions are spent annually on training following this model. What might corporate and public agency training look like (and what might its costs be) if work and workplaces were designed to foster learning as part of work practice rather than as an interruption in it?45 Similarly, although professional schools often incorporate a training element (from practicals to internships to residencies), the curricula in such schools are often quite divorced from the training. In some cases, the explicit justification for this is the perceived need to master the theory to enable the practice. Although we would not disparage at all the need for professional education that includes absorbing theories and other forms of inherited wisdom or even raw information, we would question the justification. Accordingly, we believe there is room to reexamine the design of professional programs with an eye to greater linkages between the “theory” and “training” elements. Seeing practice as necessary for knowing could be a fruitful point of reference in such redesign. The domain of public policy also reflects the deeply rooted nature of the Received View. The difficulty of accounting for policy implementation and evaluation solely in terms of acquiring and deploying necessary knowledge has by now been well established. The extent to which this difficulty is exacerbated by and persists due to the influence of the Received View has not been sufficiently explored by any means. We believe that reconceptualizing such issues in terms of the practice perspective we have outlined could prove to be a useful contribution to the field. Overall, it is our hope that what we have suggested here is deserving of further exploration.

This is not just a deficit in social theory or public administration. Philosophers have been struggling with the closely related concept of experience, and its relationship with knowledge, since its classical Greek origins. Jay, in his masterful history of the notion of experience in philosophy frames it as a struggle—perhaps oscillation is the better term (McDowell, 1996)—between empiricism and idealism (Jay, 2005). Since the classical Pragmatists have revived the concept, things have hardly improved. For example, Bernstein (2010), in his excellent chapter on “Experience after the Linguistic Turn,” observes that “One of the most controversial discussions among historians and feminists has been about whether the so-called linguistic turn displaces the direct appeal to experience” (p. 126). One could even wonder how controversial this issue really is among those who have turned the linguistic or argumentative corner, given the decided preference for obtuse, abstract theory in much interpretive, poststructuralist writing in public administration and public policy analysis.
The term entanglement in this context is from Hilary Putnam (1981).

Of the three “applied” disciplines which deal with collective problem solving—planning, public administration, and public policy analysis—public administration occupies a middle position where it comes to the acknowledgment of the role of practice in explaining what its practitioners do, and in integrating is and ought. Planning has a long-standing affiliation with pragmatist ideas and concepts to the point that these are now integral to much planning theory and practice (Friedman, 1973, 1987; Forester, 1999, 2009; Healey, 1997, 2009; Hoch, 1994; Innes & Booher, 2005, 2010; Wagenaar, 2011b). Policy analysis, by contrast, is still firmly in the grip of the Cartesian world view. While, in the last three decades, hermeneutics and poststructuralism have swept through the theory of public policy, this has done little to integrate notions of practice and experience in understanding what it is that policy makes do, let alone in suggesting what they might do to improve their practices. Flyvbjerg’s book on phronesis is a lonely and valiant attempt to turn the tide; whereas Wagenaar (2008, 2011a) has argued for a dialogical approach to policy analysis. Although public administration has also seen its share of poststructuralist theorizing, it has at least experienced an important debate about the contribution of pragmatist thought to the field. Although this debate lacks the breadth and finesse of pragmatist thought in planning, and at times is overtly abstract (such as Harmon’s otherwise admirable book), it tries at least to articulate how core pragmatist concepts such as “experience” would work in public administration, and how common administrative tasks can be reorganized along pragmatist principles (see, in particular, the work of Patricia Shields in this respect). Interestingly, both in American and European public administration there are developments that, although they do not wear their pragmatist credentials on their sleeve, are certainly pragmatist in spirit and practice. We are thinking here of participatory forms of service delivery under the banners of civic capacity (de Souza Briggs, 2008; Stone, Henig, Jones, & Pierannunzi, 2001) and public value management, respectively (Stoker, 2006). Yet in many administrative institutions, one witnesses a depressing gap between the doctrine of public administration (with its all too real implications for administrative design, organizational process, and human resource management) and the practice of public administration “on-the-ground” (Duiveman, Wagenaar, & Kruiter, 2010).
For a brilliant treatment of one aspect of it, see, Taylor (1995b, pp. 1-20).

We are, in our critique of the Cartesian epistemology, of course, highly indebted to Charles Sanders Peirce. Peirce mostly takes aim at Descartes’ appeal to universal doubt and subjective consciousness as procedures for arriving at certain knowledge (Peirce, 1992, ch. 3). But Bernstein rightly concludes that the impact of Peirces’s critique of Descartes has a much wider reach, in effect “(demolishing) the interrelated motifs that constitute Cartesianism.” He then lists these motifs as follows: “the ontological dualism of mind and body; the subjective individualism implicit in the appeal to direct personal verification; the method of universal doubt that is supposed to lead us to incorrigible truths; the conviction that unless we discover firm foundations for knowledge we cannot avoid epistemological skepticism; the belief that knowledge of the world consists of having ideas that correctly represent and correspond to this world; the doctrine that “vagueness” is unreal and that the epistemological endeavor is to know clearly and distinctly a completely determinate reality; and, most fundamentally, that we can break out of language or systems of signs and have direct, immediate knowledge of non-linguistic objects” (Bernstein, 2010, p. 18). If we run through this listing of Cartesian dogmas, the tenacity of the Cartesian world view will become immediately obvious.

One challenge in addressing traditional epistemology is that we automatically evoke a series of deeply embedded dichotomies that underlie how we see ourselves in relation to the world. We think here of such common dualisms as actor versus context, structure versus agency, mind versus body, knowledge and action, pure and applied knowledge, language and experience, and fact and value –dichotomies that Harmon (2006), for example, so tirelessly challenges in public administration. In keeping with what we have said above, there is a tendency to assume a particular ordering of self and world, knower and known, which we argue hardly holds in the experience of ordinary people acting in and with the world. The problems engendered by such dualities are too extensive to discuss in any detail here. To do justice to its their many ramifications, which all resonate with each other in complex and often unexpected patterns, would require a separate publication. We would mention here just a few points that are relevant to the theme of this article. The mind–body duality directly descends very strongly from the representationalism of the 17th-century scientific revolution. The challenge has been framed as liberation from religious and metaphysical superstition that affords an epistemically correct and truthful representation of an observer-independent external reality. This set in motion a host of reactions, some of which remain at play to this very day. One is the intense proceduralism of traditional epistemology deriving centrally from Descartes’ attempts to secure confidence in the outcomes of one’s thinking, and his conflation of truth and justification (Toulmin, 1990). As is well-known, reason came to be firmly tied to following carefully prescribed procedures, to the point that in much of modern, established epistemology, reason and rationality are synonymous with following methodological procedure. A second is the disappearance of the body from awareness (Leder, 1990). The act of knowing is understood to take place in the mind—although this has been increasingly challenged by the need to account for the role of the body in various forms of knowing. This is seen in such everyday experiences as “muscle memory” or the disappearance into the background of subtle skills of judgment and motion in the course of learning a complex skill such as sailing or driving a car (even in the realm of mental experience, we must account for the likes of Proust’s fabled “madeleine”). Another ramification of the disappearance of the body from awareness is the primacy that is accorded to language as something that is both opposed to and superior to experience—consider the “text metaphor” in hermeneutics, anthropology, and the social sciences (Ricoeur, 1977). There is a tendency here to treat language as a representation of experience, as if experience cannot be “known” in any other way and can only be mediated by language. There has been something of an eclipse of the notion that language is itself a modality of “being-in-the world” (and a very important one for self-reflective beings) working alongside and in interaction with other modalities in constituting ourselves as the oriented, engaged agents we are (Csordas, 1995, p. 11). It is this crisscrossing of such deeply burrowed predilections and assumptions that make it particularly difficult to find a clear, unencumbered language for stating an alternative perspective.

We are certainly not the only ones who struggle with the conditioning effects of the concepts and language of the Received View when discussing practice. In her important and thoughtful book, The Body Multiple, the Dutch philosopher–anthropologist Annemarie Mol, for example, discusses the various terms that are in use for moving away from a “realist” perspective of (social) science and the subject–object dichotomy. After discussing, and rejecting, performance and construction, she finally settles for enacting:

disp-quote.p: This, then, may be a way out of the dichotomy between the knowing subject and the objects-that-are-known: to spread the activity of knowing widely. To spread it out over tables, knives, records, microscopes, buildings, and other things or habits in which it is embedded. Instead of talking about subjects knowing objects we may, then, as a next step, come to talk about enacting reality in practice. (Mol, 2007, p. 50; emphasis in original)

fn.p: There are, of course, historical antecedents to the idea that practice can have a role in what and how we know, and such antecedents have been increasingly explored in contemporary social theory and social science (for example, Flyvbjerg, 2001; Harmon, 2006, p. 65). Of particular value in recent years has been work building on Aristotle’s concept of phronesis or practical wisdom, acting well or appropriately in a given situation (in a casual sense, this is akin to savoir fare). Phronesis is acquired over time and through experience. It involves the ability to generalize over a set of past situations in determining how best to act in a present one. Although phronesis points to the idea of knowledge acquired and refined in practice, ultimately that knowledge can still (and often is) treated as making phronesis possible: one acquires over time, knowledge that enables one to act in ways that display phronesis. So as a general rule, this remains within the Received View’s privileging of knowledge as prior to and enabling of practice.
Oakeshott captures this very effectively in a comparison with cooking:

disp-quote.p: It might be supposed that an ignorant man, some edible materials, and a cookery book compose together the necessities of a self-moved (or concrete) activity called cooking. But nothing is further from the truth. The cookery book is not an independently generated beginning from which cooking can spring; it is nothing more than an abstract of somebody’s knowledge of how to cook: it is the stepchild, not the parent of the activity . . . .(Oakeshott, 1962)

fn.p: The Modified View accounts in this way for the unexplained relation between knowledge and the external world. See Taylor (1995b) for a discussion of this.
For a fuller exploration of such implications of the tacit/explicit distinction, see Cook and Brown (1999).

We argue for this as follows. Imagine, for example, a musical instrument technician adjusting the key mechanism on a flute. The key mechanism is a system of levers whose tension is set by a number of pin springs. For the mechanism to work and feel right, the tension on the springs has to be set properly. This is something a master technician must be able to do, and an apprentice must learn. A master technician might know that a particular spring should be set somewhere between X and Y grams of resistance as measured with a tension gauge. Since this is something that can be said, it is an explicit form of knowing-that. The technician must also be able to judge exactly where between X and Y that spring needs to be set: at some point he or she will know that the key feels right. But the subjective feeling is not something he or she can express explicitly, so this bit of knowing-that is tacit (the technician might say “now it feels right,” but this is a report about the spring being set properly, not a report of what the feeling actually is). Importantly, what enables the technician to know that the key feels right rests with his or her ability to judge the feel of keys—this is something the technician knows how to do, but this knowledge is not something he or she can say (as with knowing that the key feels right). This is an example of knowing-how that is tacit (it is important to note that knowing-how to judge the feel of keys and knowing-that a particularly key feels right are two different things: one is the ability to judge, the other is making a particular judgment). Finally, we would note there are all kinds of things people explicitly say related to what they know how to do. These would be examples of know-how that is explicit. It is important to note the nature of this kind of knowledge. Things said here are not expressed in forms whose truth or falsity can be determined (in contrast to explicit forms of knowing-that). They are not simply reports of what we know how to do. Rather, they constitute a form of knowledge expressed in the likes of metaphors and images (they are explicit, but not literal). So, the technician might say judging keys entails having a sense of the way “they are kind of bouncy” or that it’s “like pressing on a balloon.” Anyone who has taken lessons in a sport or in musical performance will be familiar with an abundance of metaphors and images teachers use to express explicitly things that are intimately linked to (but which cannot be reduced to) the performance of skills—to tacit know-how. When a vocal coach says “as you sing that phrase, let the air come out like a stream of water flowing over your tongue,” the singer must come to know how to use this explicit expression in a way that is coordinated with what he or she knows how to do tacitly when singing. Tacit forms of knowing-that (like the technician knowing-that “the key now feels right”) are, of course, acquired over time, they are, indeed, one of the hallmarks of acquired expertise. This, we note in passing, calls into question Ryle’s contention that it is only knowing-how and not knowing-that which is learned over time.

At best, we can try to control some elements of context to make it work for us. We can, for example, apply heat to iron ore so that we extract the pure iron and mold it into a desired shape. But to be able to do that we have to honor the natural, immutable qualities of heat and iron. We cannot, for example, shape a spoon out of piece of iron ore by just hammering on it (Keller & Keller, 1996). The same self-possessiveness applies to social context. The actions of one individual will not necessarily change an institution. Institutions are larger than we are. They do change of course, but usually slowly, as the result of thousands of actions of many individuals over an extended period of time.
In fact, in the Received View values are often treated as nonknowledge, as something counter to knowledge, as eruptions of feeling that are a threat to the integrity of knowledge.
Compare Wenger (1998), “I intend the term negotiation to convey a flavour of continuous interaction, of gradual achievement, and of give-and-take” (p. 56).

The term setting thus transcends the dichotomy between context as a fixed, observer-independent, system of structures and constraints impinging on the actor and the ethnomethodological notion of context as purely constructed in the interactive experiences of actors. Setting encompasses both. Describing the way housewives purposefully move about in a supermarket, Lave (1988) formulates the notion of setting as follows:

disp-quote.p: On the one hand, context connotes an identifiable, durable framework for activity, with properties that transcend the experience of individuals, exist prior to them, and are entirely beyond their control. On the other hand, context is experienced differently by different individuals. The apparently contradictory features of the term may be accounted for by recognizing that in ordinary usage context refers to relations between arena and setting rather than to a single entity. There is a distinction to be made here between the constraints imposed by the supermarket as arena and the constructable, malleable nature of the setting in relation with the activity of particular shoppers. Because a social order and the experience of it mutually entail one another, there are limits on both the obdurate and malleable aspects of every context. A setting is generated out of a person’s grocery-shopping activity and at the same time generates that activity. (p. 151)

fn.p: Lave’s words are echoed by Stolcis (2004) when he describes the everyday practice of administrators:

disp-quote.p: Contemporary public administration practice operates in a problem-solving fashion within the framework of its constitutional authority. Part of the practice of modern governance is in determining the boundaries of our constitutional and legal authority and in crafting realistic problem-solving strategies that respect these boundaries. This is the coin of the practice realm. Responsible practitioners quickly learn to successfully operate and administer within the confines of their constitutional authority. Those who do not master this skill typically have a brief, and often unhappy, career in the practice world. (p. 364)

fn.p: For persuasive, “on-the-ground” descriptions of this practical negotiating of the obdurate and the malleable, the given and the constructed, in dealing with the kind of problems that experienced practitioners face, see for example Maynard-Moody and Musheno (2003), or, in the field of planning, Krumholz and Forester (1990).

It is this duality, being simultaneously inside our conventions and out there in the world, that Dewey aims to capture in his central concept of “experience”—and, we should add, has frequently been misunderstood by his critics as constituting some kind of foundationalism (see, for example, Miller, 2004). What makes an experience the experience it is for Dewey is what he calls its “pervasive quality,” something that is immediately felt and that is unique to that particular experience. In that sense, experiences are not just subjective or mere words that could have been otherwise. Yet, what makes an experience an experience for a particular person, that makes it stand out from the flow of random noise around us, and that makes it indubitably manifest itself as an experience, is the history of the interaction of a particular actor and her environment. It is this interaction, stretched out in emergent time and suffused with the purposes of the actor that gives experiences their unique, urgent character (Dewey, 1994. See also, Bernstein, 2010, pp. 146-147).
We are influenced here in one respect by Kuhn (1977).
This phrasing draws on Sir Geoffrey Vickers (personal communication, 1980).
Or, as Bernstein (2010) summarizes it: “Dewey, approaches inquiry and knowing from the perspective of those experiences or indeterminate situations that become problematic for us” (p. 147).

A number of implications follow from this approach to practice that deserve emphasis. First, it is a clear instance of the general antidualism of Dewey’s (and Lave’s) position. With his use of the term situation, he suggests what can be taken as an ecological view of the relation of actor and his or her environment. According to Dewey, there exists a strong continuity between actor and environment. Actors are not distinct objects, but form, with their environment, a “living system”, or as Burke, an astute Dewey scholar, characterizes it, “a dynamic system incorporating both organismic and environmental elements, with some sort of built-in impetus towards self-maintenance” (Burke, 1994, p. 27). The Deweyan heritage can be found as well in Engeström’s concept of an activity system, in Wengers concept of a “community of practice,” and in Vicker’s notion of an “appreciative system” (Engeström, 1993; Vickers, 1965/1995; Wenger, 1998). Practices are thus not just a patterned fabric of activities, but also contain the spaces and artifacts that are necessary to fulfill the practice. For example, the practice of teaching requires a classroom, a black board, textbooks, and so on (Elmore, 1996). Second, it is important to observe that such conversations with the world involve engagement with the task at hand and active participation in the community that forms the social setting of that activity (Vickers, 1965/1995). This implies that practice involves the whole person instead of a disengaged actor who receives information or acquires knowledge about preexisting objects (Lave & Wenger, 1991). Engaging in practice implies that the actor’s identity is involved. But, to avoid misunderstanding at this point, identity should not be understood in its familiar subjective meaning but in a social sense. That is, we define our identity in terms of our experiences with membership in various groups (Wenger, 1998).
Cook and Brown (1999) draw a distinction between knowledge and knowing in exploring this sense of practice.
Or as Ralph Waldo Emerson (1934) put it in the middle of the 19th century, in our efforts to understand ourselves and our actions “there is always a residuum unknown and unanalyzable.”

With the exception of certain kinds of rational decision analysis (see Stokey & Zeckhauser, 1976). However, a problem with these kinds of forward looking analytic tools is that they can artificially confine the full field of action possibilities, to only a limited number of permissible decision alternatives.

This deep pluralism is, of course, one of the core themes of pragmatism. Pragmatist thinkers, from William James to Hilary Putnam espouse the realization that “our visions are always finite, partial and incomplete” (Bernstein, 2010, p. 60). One way to understand the pragmatist project is to come to terms, both metaphysically and ethically, with pluralism/perspectivism.
The sketch of the vice squad’s work is drawn from research by (HW) as part of a project on administrative practice.

The concept of “ongoing business” builds on the dual nature of experience, the encompassing of setting and subject, mind and world, in one overarching, dynamic, developing concept, another core theme of pragmatism. This is beautifully captured by Bernstein (2010) when he describes Dewey’s Hegelian roots:

disp-quote.p: Dewey’s, in effect naturalized Hegel. Dewey’s concept of experience as a transaction that spans space and time, involving both undergoing and activity, shows the Hegelian influence. Subject and object are understood as functional distinctions within the dynamics of a unified developing experience. (p. 92, emphasis in original)

fn.p: For exploration of cognate ideas, see Schein (2004), Weick (2000), Cook (1982), and Cook and Yanow (1993).

This point may find something of a parallel in the work of some phenomenologists. The course we wish to take with it, however, is radically different, as we acknowledge, following pragmatist thinking, the “pervasive quality” (Dewey), the “outward clash” (Peirce) of experience.

Or as Einstein (1922/1956, p. 2) trenchantly put it (no doubt with other things in mind), “The only justification for our concepts and system of concepts is that they serve to represent the complex of our experiences; beyond this they have no legitimacy.”
Within Zen theory and practice (and in keeping with Nishida), this “nothingness” includes ourselves.
For a contemporary Western version of this multiplicity, and how it is dealt with, see Annemarie Mol’s (2003) fascinating anthropology of a modern hospital The Body Multiple.

There are fascinating analogies here with Pierce’s famous distinction of three categorical aspects of experience, in particular his notion of “secondness” (Peirce, 1998, ch. 20). However, it would go too far in the context of this article to explore the differences and similarities between these two ontological systems.

For Nishida, this does not in any way lend itself to being a solipsistic view since both the self and the self among others are generated within conscious experience and neither has priority over the other. We would add that this underscores the intersubjective or transactional character of practice.
This being not far removed from the sense we would like to make of the statement by Einstein noted above.

There are, of course, themes within Western philosophy that to a degree resonate with the view we are proposing here. One might even be tempted to find examples of this in such classical icons as Descartes’s cogito ergo sum and Kant’s treatment of noumena and phenomena. However, the net effect of the Western view, as we have noted, treats epistemology as primary and characterizes knowledge as prior to and enabling of practice. Our aim in making use of Nishida is to help counterbalance this net effect. In the West, even those who may propose a thought experiment that, like Descartes’s, begins with experience, typically end up offering a positivist ontology in keeping with an epistemology that makes knowledge a prerequisite for understanding the world and acting on it. There seems to be a predilection to believe that it is in getting our epistemological house in order that we are then able to address matters of ontology, practice, and so on. Charles Taylor characterizes this as a kind of doctrine whose assumptions “give epistemology pride of place. These are assumptions Descartes gave articulation to; central is the view that we can somehow come to grips with the problem of knowledge, and then later proceed to determine what we can legitimately say about other things: about God, or the world, or human life. From Descartes’s standpoint, this seems not only a possible way to proceed, but the only defensible way. Because, after all, whatever we say about God or the world represents a knowledge claim. So, first we ought to be clear about the nature of knowledge, and about what it is to make a “defensible claim” (Taylor, 1995, p. vii). This predilection does not obtain in Nishida. Although the Cartesian cogito ergo sum characterizes being as entailed in thought, Nishida begins first and always with an undifferentiated consciousness (or “nothingness”) within which both being and thought are then created. It is this that helps to provide a foothold for understanding practice—at root, the generative activities of consciousness—as prior to what we know and to the world that we construct.
There is something of the sense of this in the distinction between the noun “knowledge” and the verb “knowing.” For one exploration of the implications of this distinction, see Cook and Brown (1999).
This can be seen, for example, in the work of Hiroshi Shimizu of the Kanazawa Institute of Technology.

Nishida’s understanding of basho is rather complex and subtle, and has been a subject of discussion and debate among philosophers and others ever since he introduced it (see, for example, Kopf, 2003). For our purposes here, a core expression of it will suffice.
There is something of the feel of this in the words “milieu” and “locus.”
There are interesting analogies here with the way that the hospital personnel in Annemarie Mol’s book try to unify the multiple “realities” of atherosclerosis into one unified “disease” (Mol, 2003).
